STRINGS: We jumped into the car as soon as we
confirmed Takenaka's address.
On the way there, I told Mr. Kazamori
everything that I heard from Sekimoto.
"The horror story that bastard made up for
his experiment became real, huh...?
That's one helluva tale, isn't it?"
"I'm sure he has some ulterior motive for
wanting to see how this all turns out
to the point of suspending his own trial."
"But, he also said he was responsible for this."
"So... his intentions are complicated, basically."
Frankly speaking, I can't even guess what he's thinking.
We ordinary people cannot fathom a man driven by pure
intellectual curiosity like him.
"Hey, Houjou, can I ask you something--?
How do you think that guy views all of this?"
"This is only speculation, okay?"
I pondered for a moment to choose my words carefully.
"...He's probably quite pleased with himself."
"Well, considering it's that guy, yeah, I can see it."
The monster he created has become real and is running wild,
not to mention that the investigation is at his mercy now.
There is no urban legend as thrilling as this,
so I have no doubts that he feels a sense of
accomplishment as its creator.
Since this is Sekimoto were talking about,
he probably wants to get as close as possible
and see how this all plays out.
"Blindman and Sekimoto are
equally messed up in the head."
"If, hypothetically, Blindman and his creator--
Soujirou Sekimoto were to come face to face,
I wonder what would happen."
"Do you think they'd get all emotional?"
"Nope."
"Yep.
I'd bet he'd plunge those scissors
right into Sekimoto's grinnin' face."
After that, we drove in silence for a while.
Our destination was on the edge of C Town.
I believe this district is for prefecture-run public housing.
However, there shouldn't be very many people living in here.
The area should be nearing closure due to depupolation.
"What do we do once we get there, Mr. Kazamori?
Look at the time, we don't even have a courtesy letter.
I doubt we'll get a voluntary interview..."
It's almost midnight.
Normally, no detective would make a simple
house call at this time of night.
In the unlikely event of him being a suspect,
he would be poised to destroy evidence.
"To be honest, I feel like we jumped the gun a bit here..."
"Hey, Houjou.
I want ya to just answer me with your gut on this one."
"...Okay. What is it?"
"The guy we're going to interrogate--
this, uh, so-and-so Takenaka.
Do you think he's a decent person?"
Without thinking, I fell silent.
Sensing this, Mr. Kazamori put his hand in his breast pocket.
"If you, at any point,
feel that something bad is gonna happen,
I want you to unhook your baton and handcuffs. Got it?"
"...Alright."
"Oh wow... This is pretty bad.
Even more than I expected."
As we stepped out of the car,
we couldn't believe our eyes at the sight before us.
The public housing area was lined up with
houses of the same design, all of which had fallen into ruin.
Weeds thrived about in disorder,
indicating that no humans have been here for quite some time.
"Houjou... Where's Takenaka's place?"
"At the far end."
We proceeded with caution,
trying to make as little noise as possible.
"I think this is the house."
I pointed to a single-story residence on
the far end of the herd of housing.
There were no lights turned on inside the house.
It's as still as death. Has he already gone to bed in the evening?
I returned to my observation of Takenaka's residence.
There seems to be a lot of piled-up mail at the door.
The instruments used in everyday life had become all dusty.
The curtains, seen through the window, were half-opened.
The shutters weren't in place.
Mr. Kazamori approached the window cautiously,
and peered inside the house.
"...Mr. Kazamori?
Can you see anything?"
"Ah, shit!
Houjou, call for backup!!"
He suddenly shouted and grabbed the doorknob,
trying to open the front door, but it wouldn't budge.
"Mr. Takenaka! Can you hear me?
This is the police, please open the door!
I said, open the door!!"
Without any hesitation, he took out his baton,
smashed through the window, and unlocked the door.
The moment the door was opened,
stagnant air that had been accumulating flooded out.
At the same time, a number of flies began to swarm.
The smell of dust was suffocating.
Blended with it was an indescribable smell of decay,
like that of kitchen waste left unattended.
With the flashlights we brought from the car,
Mr. Kazamori and I illuminated the interior.
That's when we saw what was in there--
Three bodies. An old man and woman, and a relatively young man.
The younger corpse was probably Mr. Takenaka.
Due to high humidity, their skin had already melded with the floor
and become discolored, reaching putrefaction.
Innumerable maggots had taken the opportunity and
gorged upon their flesh. In some parts, bone was clearly visible.
I could feel the involuntary backflow of gastric fluids.
But I desperately suppressed it, as to not ruin the crime scene.
"Houjou... It happened again."
I fixed my gaze on the points where he was shining his light,
the victims' faces.
It's clear that a considerable amount of time had past since death.
Judging by their appearance, their eyes had been gouged out.
In fact, pairs of blood-rusted scissors laid nearby.
And near their slightly opened mouths,
there were traces that their tongues had been cut out.
"Blind...man...!?"
"This is the third incident..."
"No. They've been left to rot for some time.
They were probably the first to be killed."
"Dammit!! Do you see this, Houjou!?
This means that Blindman's been hidin' in this town
even before we noticed his presence!!"
"We've been oblivious all along!!
He's been right under our noses the whole time,
that murderous bastard!"
Just as Mr. Kazamori started to vent his frustrations,
the sound of sirens was heard outside, signaling backup's arrival.
If only--
If only Mr. Takenaka were still alive,
then we would have gotten to the bottom of this mystery already.
But the monster that lurks in this depopulated town
had already crushed that possibility,
as if he knew our every move before we even made them.
And not only that, but this occurred a long time ago.
I'm sure that thing was having a good time, laughing at us.
I never thought it would have turned out this way.
We informed the detectives that had arrived from
the First Investigative Division of the situation,
and shortly after, the initial investigation begun.
Once we told them just enough to grasp the situation,
they moved on, ignoring our presence.
When the Section Chief told us we could leave,
Mr. Kazamori cursed at him, calling him a damned hyena,
stealing the credit of our hard work.
